title: Improving Adherence Healthy Lifestyle on a Smartphone Based on Complementation Adults With Intellectual Disabilities
description_brief: AIM: Improve adherence to physical activity in people with Intellectual disabilities with a Smartphone Application DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial SUBJECTS OF THE STUDY: People with intellectual disabilities in Occupational Center ( ASPROMANIS) INTERVENTION: DATA ANALYSIS: descriptive statistics, measuring central tendency and dispersion of the variables study. Inferential statistics will be made between intervention of key variables and outcome
explanation_target: Reason: The trial description and title describe a smartphone (mHealth) application to improve adherence to physical activity in adults with intellectual disabilities — a behavioral/technology intervention, not a pharmacologic agent or biologic. The aim is to increase physical activity adherence (health behavior), so it does not match the four Alzheimer-specific therapeutic categories (disease-targeted biologic, disease-targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). citeturn0search3turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details from the description — Title: "Improving Adherence Healthy Lifestyle on a Smartphone Based on Complementation Adults With Intellectual Disabilities"; Design: randomized controlled trial; Intervention: smartphone application (reminders/monitoring) to improve adherence to physical activity; No drug or placebo is mentioned. Relevant published protocols / reports for similar studies (demonstrating this is an mHealth RCT rather than a drug trial) include an open-access article and protocol describing app-based PA adherence interventions in adults with intellectual disabilities and related mHealth trials. Examples: "Improving Adherence Physical Activity with a Smartphone Application Based on Adults with Intellectual Disabilities (APPCOID)" (full text/PMC). citeturn0search3 Additional related mHealth PA trial publications/protocols: BMC/Trials articles and PubMed entries on smartphone apps to increase physical activity. citeturn0search0turn0search1
